>>9621347
>The Japanese katakana is literally アナ (Ana).
Appeal to isolation and ambiguity fallacy. Kana is not always used analogously to Latin characters or English phonetics. Context and official sources (like here >>9616958) are always significant and erase any ambiguity. Otherwise, you'd be arguing that Super Mario Sehtaa (セーター, not Sweater スエター (suetaa)) is the correct title for that NES knitting game and that Baacha Fighter (バーチャ, not Virtua ヴェーチュア (veechua)) is the name of that 3D fighting game series. But you wouldn't, as you know that would be gibberish.

These are just two examples of Japanese media using kana irregularly. Kana can be used irregularly and yet still intend to mean, in this case, Anna (as all the official sources write it in Roman characters that way). The official sources are not making a mistake with Roman characters (as I'm sure you assume), rather, you are.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Loid is, as far I know, an L/R flip made by the early days of the Starmen.Net fandom, before Super Smash Bros. stickers/spirits codified the names. Japanese sources always called him "Roid".

However, I would argue that this name is a perfectly intentional juxtaposition from the character's appearance! You see, if you swapped Teddy ane Roid around, their names would be more fitting. Teddy gives the image of someone as soft and cudley as a teddy bear. Roid gives you the idea that this person has roid rage. But clearly, in the game, it is Teddy that is the steroid abuser and Roid that is the soft one. This creates a scene in which the two are diametrically at odds with each other. Indeed, one cannot have both Roid and Teddy in the party, because Teddy will dismiss Roid as a "weakling".This stirs up a sense of rage within our dear boy. While he does not literally succumb to roid rage from what we see, he nonetheless is rageful enough to plant a robot that isn't there when Teddy isn't in the party, steal a combat tank, and feign the party's rescue as he obliterates Teddy. This cripples Teddy into becoming a proverbial teddy bear, while Roid shows off that he too was worthy of his namesake in the end. After all, it was Socrates who said, “We can easily forgive a child who is afraid of the dark; the real tragedy of life is when men are afraid of the light.” Indeed, Teddy perceived of Roid as a "weakling" because he embodies qualities endemic to bullied children, and rather than take the high road, is fixed on his quest for the death of his parents and in turn as someone who is hurt lashes out and bullies the bullied. The truth is that the mountain monster who slayed Teddy's patents was unsuspectedly under his nose the whole time: Roid. It was Roid's robot that also did in Teddy's parents. He was also planning to destroy Teddy, but remembered that Nintendo and Anna did not wrong him and came up with a cover. Beware the silent ones, they say, or Roid will show his Rage.

if you look at the game files to see how it prioritizes alien missions it's actually quite cute and you can see how the game designers planned everything out. different alien species have different probabilities of doing a particular mission, and different regions get different mission probabilities.

>Europe gets a lot of infiltration missions because it's a major X-COM funding area
>but alien bases are rare there because aliens prefer to put those in more sparsely populated areas
>Southeast Asia gets a lot of abduction missions due to its huge population density
and so forth

>>9619631
The original is a very special game. Its well balanced, well designed and manages to be unnerving, despite the horrifically bad voice actors ruining the tone. It is somewhat archaic, which holds it back, but it's an easy 8/10

RE2 is an improvement in many ways, but it's troubled development shows. They basically just recreated the first game with different names for similar environments and mostly the same pacing and design reused.
That said, it's probably the best overall game of the original 3, as it perfects the formula of the original, adds in some good original concepts and has the best plot. 9/10

I have always seen RE3, Dino Crisis 2 and Onimusha as sister games, as they are all stabs at making action games out of traditional RE gameplay conventions.
RE3 is very repayable, fast paced and overall pretty fun, but it suffers from worse pacing and some optional backtracking being a pain in the ass due to how long it can take. It also feels more linear and takes place almost entirely on long, narrow paths. If it wasn't fun to play, it would score lower, but it's an 8/10 IMO

Code Veronica feels like a step backwards from 3 in terms of control and gameplay, it's not as well designed as 1 and 2, so it is basically just average feeling.
It has the least that sets it apart from the rest of the series. And it is the first entry to have an outright bad story. 7/10, but I'm being generous

REmake is an interesting animal. I feel like in terms of pacing and overall design, it's the ultimate survival horror game. But I also feel like it misses the mark as a remake. It's tonedeaf to what the original game was. It's also slower and the controls are more awkward than the first 4 games as well.
I adore it, but if it wasn't so pretty, most people wouldn't like it as much as they do. 8/10

Zero is another code veronica in many ways, except it manages to set itself apart with character zapping. 7.5/10

RE4 is none of the things you are describing.
The reason RE4 exists the way it does is due to the development hell it went through, it originally started as RE3 back in 1998 after 2 concluded production, that's how bad it was. Mikami was disappointed by how 2's development went (there's a reason he calls CV the true 2, as gameplay wise it is a full evolution instead of half steps like 2 and 3).
The RE3 turned 4 project was just a melting pot of ideas for a long time. Kamiya's "Project Devil" got spun into its own thing, the girl and dog idea became Haunting Ground, the Hookman idea stagnated, etc.
When Mikami took over he probably just wanted to actually have something come out after like 8 years of constant development leading to nothing. "Dropping all of the bloat", which he didn't. He still used Flagship's concepts for the game, there's just little there because Mikami isn't a writer (that's why all of REmake's story additions suck ass, and the stuff people cite as good are shit like the Trevor files which Iwao wrote during 1's production). Leon gets infected, Wesker is working in the background against the antagonist, Ada Wong returns, Leon fights through a castle, these are all from the last concept Flagship/Sugimura submitted for 4, 4 even leans on Wesker going "We have to revive Umbrella," it does nothing to ditch the bloat. Fucking Wesker IS the "bloat" of RE, Umbrella was the actual antagonist!
>It still has tank controls and item management.
The item management is completely different retard.
You know nothing.

They thought it wouldn't be wise to have a game full of just speed - not only was that a part of US marketing only, but also playtesters were finding the speed so sickening that Green Hill had to be toned down. With this, they decided that the game should switch between fast zones and slow zones. They did intend the players to find ways to gain speed in any zone, as, for example, there are barely any sections where pushing blocks is actually required to proceed in Marble, and in Act 3, there's a large shortcut with rewards for finding it, but it's obvious that the pacing and design of Marble, Labyrinth and Scrap Brain are different from Green Hill, Spring Yard and Starlight.

>>9624547
going fast was a marketing thing more than a design thing. The game is more designed off of pinball than off of racing cars. Sometimes the ball moves quickly, other times the ball moves in a tricky way that must be mastered through practice and focus. That's why momentum is more important than speed. If you just make a sonic game with nothing but speed, you get the boost games.

As for complaints of repetition, it's an arcade game with levels designed in 1991. It's a home console from one of the biggest arcade devs and one that routinely designed games around practice and memorization being key toward being able to beat a game or to get a high score. What did you expect to be doing in this game? Idiots act like having to remember something about the game or having to practice the layouts makes it inherently bad. Next you'll complain about having to remember the controls too. If anything, you should be happy; Sonic is by far one of the easiest games Sega ever put out. It would be sad to see you try and beat games like Space Harrier on Hardest or Streets of Rage 2 on Mania. Those games have baby modes on them too, but recognize that their baby mode is basically the same as Sonic's difficulty, only sonic doesn't have adjustable settings so you're always stuck on Infantile.

posts.com:
Sonic was not about going fast all the time.
Going fast was for mastering the level design and finding the more rewarding routes. If you look at the levels, most of them have multi paths, usually the lower path is the noob path, and the higher paths are the get good paths, that require to use the speed, coupled with a good understanding of the game physics, to reach. Those are usually full of rings, 1ups and other p-ups.

And then there is curling into a ball, which as already stated, Marble zone is about. But Marble Zone is also a way to teach the player the physics, you have to understand how it works slow before you can take it fast.

At least that's what OP's mom says.

The Maverick Virus mutated from the Wily Virus, which was based on the Evil Energy that Wily found in Megaman 8.
According to Duo in MM8, the Evil Energy is actually a sapient alien substance that absorbs evil within robots minds and then multiplies as to infect more robots. Dr. Light found out that performing a full analysis of it was impossible (much like Zero's system). An entity made out of pure energy is an interesting concept since it can be a power source, be translated into electrical signals (and be transmitted as a virus) and even be converted into mass. Due to this method of replication, the original source can only be harnessed by beings of pure evil. The Wily virus made from it probably works in the same manner, "absorbing" Zero's destructive programming when he fought Sigma and had the migraines, and then spreading to Sigma and the rest of the reploids. Only someone who's pure evil could have it in their system and not die from it (like Wily in robot form).

That's why the Maverick Virus is so unorthodox and can do shit normal computer viruses can't.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's the plot of X4 put plainly.

Repliforce was created to supplant the need to combat Mavericks due to the growing number of riots and rebellions perpetrated by Sigma and the virus, which the Hunters could barely control on their own, as evidenced in the past three X games. Repliforce's purpose was shown to be inefficient, and the Hunters were itching for a reason to disband them. Sigma noticed this, and began orchestrating the Sky Lagoon incident.

Magma Dragoon was a Maverick Hunter and prideful warrior who's always envied X's superior fighting abilities, believing the latter always hend back whenever they sparred during training sessions. This grudge he harbored against X allowed Sigma to convince him to sabotage Sky Lagoon and become a Maverick, all so he could force X to have a real fight with him, no holds barred. Still, Dragoon's motivation to betray the Maverick Hunters wasn't enough to cause the Repliforce war, as that would come later.

When the Sky Lagoon crashes, X and Zero find evidence of Repliforce presence in the rubble. They also find Colonel investigating the crash site, who claims to be looking for his sister Iris. The Hunters immediately demand him to surrender his weapons and follow them to the Hunter base for questioning (which often ends in imprisonment or decommission for Reploids, as someone has to take the fall until the real culprits are found, if ever. After all, the Maverick virus scare is a good enough prerogative to let the Hunters point fingers at just about anyone despite their own general ineffectiveness). The Maverick Hunters immediately grow suspicious when he refuses - the image of the second-in-command of Repliforce being detained would ruin public opinion on Repliforce and basically guarantee its dissolution through vox populi.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9625818
The Hunters then demand General to disband the Repliforce and turn himself in for inquiry. Years of experience fighting Mavericks fueled the Hunters' concern that Repliforce could become dangerous, should they become infected by the Maverick Virus or grow strong enough to overpower the Hunters themselves.

The Hunters had a solid reason to be worried, but their authoritarian "do as we say or else" attitude was a big fucking insult to a man like General. Before the incident took place, Sigma warned him that this would happen sooner or later, as human beings were growing wary of armed Reploids running around (though General did not recognize Sigma during their meeting, since everyone thought he was dead for good). Sending a Repliforce representative to talk it out with the Hunters wouldn't work, since the Hunters wouldn't even give Colonel, General's right hand man, the time of day. General then decided that Repliforce should simply leave planet Earth and build a reploid colony in a space station. It wasn't a declaration of war so much as a "you don't trust us, so we're leaving" statement. The Hunters, of course, regarded their disobedience as Maverick behavior, and then the fighting began. The "Final Weapon" was originally the space station they wanted to move to, and was only turned into an actual weapon after the Hunters started going after Repliforce.

Even after the war begins, Repliforce officers like Jet Singray were shown evacuating the civilians before carrying out orders to destroy certain locations. Storm Owl's brigade was attacked by the Hunters, including X, who found himself acting just how Sigma wanted him to, when he denied Owl's accusation that the Hunters were corrupt, before executing him with a charged shot to the face.

Meanwhile, Double was sent by Sigma to Hunter base as to disrupt the flow of information and prevent any chance of peace accords between Repliforce and the Maverick Hunters from happening. And so you have Megaman X4.

>>9623382
>"Fair wage" is complete bullshit and inflames inflation and unemployment. No one can define it
Then let me give you an idea. Most ideas of "minimum wage" are based on trying to keep up with the rate of inflation relative to the arguably arbitrary number that MW started at many decades ago.

To be "fair", it should be tied not to inflation, but to the GDP and the national prosperity
as a whole. As the nation gets richer, everyone in it should get richer. So if we tie the minimum wage to per capita income, we get about $25/hr for 2020.

To be clear, that isn't the same as dividing total wealth by number of people, and then writing that as an hourly wage. If we did that the number would go way way up. The per capita income of the US is about $62,000/yr. But since only half those people are in the workforce (many are children, etc.), we double that, to get $124,000. With 2080 hours in a work year, that comes out to about $60/hr. If everyone were paid the same, that is what you might make. This doesn't take into account the open secret that the majority of the wealth of the 1% is hidden and squirreled away in offshore accounts and shell corporations.

If you don't want to tie it to the GDP of the nation, then it should be tied to profits of the employer. Every employee should get paid in a percentage, not a flat rate. Since Wal-Mart, Amazon and most other corporations are reporting record-breaking profits every year, their employees should also be seeing record-breaking earnings. If you want to claim they did not contribute or are not essential to these profits, why are they employed?

>>9626008
Computer technology advanced at a lightning pace in the 90s so better tech became available at home for reasonable prices. RAM was a big one where cost dropped quite a bit. MaskROM as well, which is why the N64 started out with 8MB carts and ended with 64MB ones. But the arcade market was also shrinking as more and more people bought home consoles so it stopped being worthwhile to invest in state of the art arcade architectures that made console ports a pain in the ass. Virtua Fighter 3 was running on a super computer but that meant no Saturn port. It was already struggling, even in Japan, but that completely destroyed it.

posts.com:
>>9615090
Just get the max pack from gog, its a pre-setup dosbox.
The win95 version is better, but not as stable. I don't think multiplayer is very important for you, so that shouldn't matter.

Carma 2 has some music issues, a basic fix is just renaming carma2_hw.exe to anything else and it should work, but it will crash everytime you quit.
The better solution is downloading _inmm.dll (a program used to get certain older implementations of audio to work), specifically https://community.pcgamingwiki.com/files/file/107-patched-_inmmdll. It contains some extra for variables carma2 (and many other games), install it.
You patch Carma2_hw.exe by just dragging it onto inmmcnf.exe (or its shortcut name _inmm.dll setup).
You then open inmmcnf.exe normally and add *.ogg (that's what the files should be) to the filetypes and set player to DirectShow (same for the default just in case).
You then go to the _inmm.ini tab and add the songs either via the button or dragging them on the list and then saving. You put the .ini it wants to save in the folder with the executable. Don't move the music folder as it points to that.

its always a larger hassle to write out _inmm instructions than actually doing it as its quite simple.

As I have said. The 3D accelerated version was something that I had on my old desktop for years. I found it via P2P network, by downloading it from another user. It was the standard disc image release of the game. But it came with a couple additional binaries for native windows compatibility with D3D rendering. The game ran flawlessly on Windows XP for me. I thought it was a standard patch that anyone could download from fileplanet or something. And then I saw the LGR videos on the original Carmageddon, and Clint mentioned how hard it was to play the game on anything but DOS. I remember leaving a comment in the video telling him to get the Direct3D patch. Which I later tried to find myself, but couldn't come up with any results online. I do remember this patch having ATI in the filename. The original Tomb Raider was released on DOS for the PC. It had multiple hardware acceleration patches for 3DFX, Matrox, S3 Virge, PowerVR, and such. But in more recent years, an ATi Direct3D windows patch surfaced, that was completely unknown outside of ATi. The Carmageddon d3d patch I had did the exact same thing, but with Carmageddon.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o6ptYJcly_w

I wish it was something that I kept. There might be a slim chance that I have it on a CDR with a bunch of other emulators and pirated software. But there is no guarantee that I have it at all.I haven't been able to find it since. the ATI patch is something that would make the original game totally playable now.

posts.com:
A good point to show how cutting edge it was.

Before it came out what was the best melee combat in 3D?

All I can think of is janky stuff that was intolerable even in it's time and stuff like FPS melee where it has no problems that have no depth what so ever.

*Multiple weapons with varying speed and hitboxes. Some weapons allow a shield, others do not.
*3 variations on the standard combo, a jump attack, a spin attack with 2 means of execution
*2 types of shields (Hyrule shield as young link is mechanically separate from wood shield/adult shield).
*Melee equipment upgrades
*Defensive rolls/dodges

Before then I think the best 3D melee was Hexen as the fighter character which is basically just 1 attack with a few weapon upgrades.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9623259
*Kings Field: Dumbed down Ultima Underworld. All combat elements and the physical world itself are inferior. The points where it is better are just a result of King's Field being a different genre: dungeon crawler vs adventure
*Goemon: I think this needs no explanation
*Alundra: It's Link to the Past with better graphics, more cutscenes, and less ambitious adventure elements. Not evnen 3D which is cutting edge at this time not just for graphics but for everything: exploration, combat, world feeling, are all bumped in 3D.
*Medevil: Different genre so hard to compare. Zelda is an adventure game about exploring, items, and NPCs. Medevil is basically a linear action with some side paths to explore or flexibility in the order you can collect the widgets. In that regard Medevil is a world of diffference less ambitious then Zelda.
*Tomb Raider: Some things in tomb raider are more advanced mostly to do with movement. But like Medevil it's just a less ambitious genre. It's a stage based linear game with cutting edge movement. The biggest and most obvious difference in ambition is Zelda is trying to create a world while Tomb Raider is not.

>>9623451
MML is better than OoT. The movement isn't as sophisticated but everything else is better designed. Equipment upgrade is more detailed and satisfying, and the town actually feels lived in, with full 3D graphics, car traffic, and more people trying to get by. The combat actually feels better with a primitive but enjoyable projectile based 3rd person shooter gameplay and a decently diverse selection of weapons, as opposed to Zelda where you're using your sword and bow 97% of the time and most of the enemies are just not fun to fight against. The hidden items aren't collectathon bullshit like heart pieces or skulltula coins or whatever that was. Tron, Roll, and all the characters are cuter than any zelda fuglies. Most zelda fanboys are drooling for link anyway rather than the girls.

All in all, it's not a perfect game, but it sure as hell was better than OoT in almost every way except graphics (even though it has its own charm) and movement controls (who cares anyway, the leg booster is fun, and at least you've got manual jumping kek).

this thread concerned a guy who said his 2600 glitched when running a Harmony cart but it was fine with normal carts. if i had to guess it's that the Harmony induced voltage sag that caused the CPU to become unstable (as it draws more power than a normal cart). spraying it with compressed air temporarily fixed the problem. he swapped the CPU with a different one and it cleared up the issue. it may be that the original 6507 was a bit twitchier about its voltage level. back in the Atari times IC manufacturing wasn't as consistent as it is today and components could have more variance in their operating characteristics.

essentially as the CPU warm ups, its power use increases and the extra power draw from the Harmony overdid it and caused it to glitch from insufficient voltage. that's just my pet theory.

Most of my consoles use SCART RGB, so they go into a SCART switch->RGB to YPbPr->Component Switch->Scaler. The component switch has dual output so I run the other output to a PVM that accepts component video. The switches are all auto so I never need to press anything.
I have a few odd consoles that have native HDMI and those go into a HDMI switch (also auto). It's quite easy to manage with the right equipment. Everything is powered and ready to play through the same HDMI input, or simply turn on the CRT if you're using analog output.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9616946
>Does anyone else find it bizarre how fucking expensive switchers are?
No, but I can understand how you would find it that way.
Like other posters said, there are some issues with quality assurance that increase the price, but that's unlikely to be the main issue.
>economy of scale
That's most likely the main issue.
It is a niche product. The are relatively few purchases of the product, which means production of the product has to remain low. Few places are producing the product and those places still have to dedicate time and resources to produce it. They have to set a price point which justifies production (and consumers' expectations).
Additional manufacturers could enter the market, but with the market being as lean as it is already every producer that engages in a short-term price war comes out a loser.
Then you have to factor in support. Support for a niche tech product.
Let's look at it from the opposite way:
>everybody poops
>lots of toilet paper needed
>lots of tp manufacturers
>fighting for shelf space/market
>cost incredibly low
>for product that's processed from sources that need years to mature
>into end result
>that billions of people deem acceptable enough to drag across their bare assholes
How much do you think it'd cost to turn trees into tactile clouds if only a few thousand people wiped their asses once every few years?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9616097
It's simple, really: Final Fantasy IV exists in a bizarro vacuum were there are no real "bad" versions of the game. The Super Famicom release? One of the earliest original versions that still holds up well. The PlayStation port? Surprisingly the best out of all the PlayStation conversions, they somehow really knocked the wait times way out of the park compared to the rest. The DS remake? Fixed handheld-constraint issues that plagued 3D Final Fantasy III. The PSP compilation? The most "complete" package and best localization overall, worst anyone can say is it don't look as good as previous PSP remakes. Even the censored/easy Super Nintendo release is still enjoyable. The only versions I'd say are outright bad are the cheap Wonderswan version -which goes to show just how bizarro-world this game really is- and the initial revision of the GBA version based on it. And maybe pixel remaster for braindead-regressing to a worse translation and casualizing a few aspects, but that's PR for you.
In short, Final Fantasy IV simply has more good options to choose from.

>>9619778
PSP expanded a few parts to fit more in line with TAY, like changing "Yang's Wife" to "Sheila" (which is a Japanese change too). Since that wasn't the goal of Pixel Remaster, they took the path of least resistance and based it on the more compatible GBA version, mildly tweaking a few parts. Similar reason why PSP was also a moderately tweaked GBA script instead of a heavily tweaked DS one - it requires less fuddling to fit in with the 2D versions. For that matter, most parts that PSP shared with DS is a consequence of TAY text being based on the at-the-time more recent DS script.
>The 2D version hasn't had a full new translation since PSX
It's maybe slightly less reworked than Final Fantasy VI on GBA, but I doubt you want to debate that it hasn't had a full new translation since SNES.

I like this approach, play THE game. You're already taking something that was good enough
to be relevent when it came out for a generation of players
and skipping it to play a cleaned up version far fewer people will ever play.

Also, PSP and DS retranslations are shit.

The reason JRPGs have lost their charm is because the industry is trying to do a one to one translation of Japanese.

It started around the time of FFX where they done voice acting. As the Japanese companies
put more effort into Western translations they took more control of the process.

So instead of some rando translating games in a way he thought would make sense, as even an amateur writer would

New translations are trying to be accurate and because of this they're incredibly bland.

Example of this would be Metal Gear Solid 1,
In the Japanese version May Ling gives Snake these fortune cookie parables which only make sense in Japanese.

For the Western release the translator wisely decided to go with war quotes. You still get Snakes puzzlement at some of them included,
but overall it was better.

Kojima fired that translator later for their changes. Very few people will think the writing improved after MGS1. It's because of the translation.

Play remaster versions of JRPGs and watch all the personality of the 90s
get drained out of the games.

Or play what made them popular here in the first place,

The PSX version of FF4 has a decent translation, as does 6 because it was done similiarly to how the
greatest games like 7, 8, and 9 were localised.

So I'd go with that or the original, but avoid anything more recent.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9625432
The story quality varies heavily from game to game as well as within each game.
A lot of them were written by large teams of writers rather than just one or two. The plots are often quite convoluted and tonal whiplash is rampant. The opposite problem of very little happening for long stretches of the game is also very common.
Character arcs failing to launch or going nowhere is another reoccurring issue.

At the same time, when the stars align and everything clicks it's a magical experience.
I'm not ashamed to admit I've teared up while playing Final Fantasy. However much the story stumbles, it always does a great job of making you care about the main cast, and watching them fall in love, sacrifice themselves for something greater, or even just get a little homesick can be incredibly powerful.

They definitely aren't for everyone. If you hate RPGs, Final Fantasy isn't likely to change your mind.
On the other hand, if you love RPGs, you owe it to yourself to at least give them a shot.

The games do not have any meaningful overarching plot outside of the few direct sequels, and there is no "Lore" to speak of.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For me personally: Ape Escape, Jumping Flash 1 and 2, and Klonoa: Door to Phantomile are all extremely aesthetically pleasing and well thought out. I extend aesthetic to include the way the game presents through audio as well, all those games have such nice color choices, character design and environments alongside music that fits impeccably to the environments.
Klonoa especially has some of my favorite enemy designs ever. There's thid part in the forest world, where you have to walk a full U-Turn path that encircles a massive wooden gear - the first time you pass it, the enemies (iirc) are flying blue Moos - the second pass, once the gear is in motion, instead contains two very alien looking enemies that appear nowhere else in the game. I never knew why they did that when it seemed so arbitrary, but my instincts are they created something cool, wanted it in the game, and put them in just to do it, just for visual variety and to just kinda be noticed. I love things like that.
I guess all 3 games sort of represent that certain type of Japanese aesthetics and design where it captures all the high notes but without it being under the umbrella of anime. I like when games do that.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9620441
>Neat to see it used over Zelda footage.

This was a go-to of Zelda trailers for a bit
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GwKLbjfjpZM&ab_channel=MellyBeanGamer
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RxMos9muPYQ&ab_channel=Kevin
It was charming. Reusing a fairly iconic instrumental music piece might be be considered a faux pas these days - as if it was "lazy" or disrespectful to the original music. But there's sort of a sense that marketing was just finding something that fit well first and foremost.

In 2004 we were slightly less connected as far as being able to track down audio samples instantly. Obviously there were people who knew the source of the music(hell I think that's how I discovered Poledouris; people on forums pointing out the source of the music), but people just saw it as a nice use of the music. Now if they tried that people would beat you over the head dropping their knowledge, speculating what Zelda's ties to Conan are, etc. Back then I think we scrutinized games a little less and it was OK for a big company to use movie music for a trailer.

You failed to mention Dreamcast has higher sampling quality for the sound effects + CD-quality music, a better bomb system that's based on destruction rather than collecting fruits (leading to faster and more dynamic gameplay), no shop system which slowed down the gameplay even more, and doesn't lag terribly like on N64. Also the DC controls are just as good as N64's after you change them to the ABXY layout, I found.

The only advantage of N64 is the scoring, but are you really going to suffer through a version that's worse in every other way just for slightly more interesting scoring mechanics...?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622925
It seems you didn't read my post saying both are pretty different and both are worth playing, so I'm not saying DC one should be discarded, but I love this game so here we go
The bomb system on Dreamcast is actually more limited (you can only shoot as many missiles as there's enemies on screen), N64 lets you fire 100 missiles at a time, even if there's no enemy on screen. It's more chaotic and requires you to have better judgement on how to spend the missile bombing. Also, collecting fruit is pretty seamless and fast, as enemies leave fruit trails behind them, all you have to do is move acordingly and don't do any mistake while moving, and you can get the fruit on your way without any need for a detour.
The shop can be navigated within seconds, even split seconds. Or you can choose to not use the shop at all, if you don't want to.
Even if you want to argue that shooting with the face buttons is ideal (it's not IMO, and the devs agree), the C-buttons are more compact and act much better as a secondary d-pad than the DC's face buttons. However, the intended way to play Bangai O on the N64 is by using the d-pad to move and the stick to shoot. Might take some time to get used to it but once it clicked I could never go back to the face buttons.
Both versions are worth it, I think DC is better for beginners and N64 better for people who want more challenge. And thankfully both games offer enough changes, both gameplay wise and in presentación, that both are worth it and neither discarded.
By the way the music is different in both games, totally different conpositions.
I still don't know why are we discussing Bangai O on a co-op thread but hey, I love this game, wish it had a co-op mode.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9621756
>It got really stale after a while and my dad who was 7 at the time was too old for a lot of the overlay games
The overlay games were just a flop in general. There's a reason Magnavox' next console, the Odyssey 100, was just a slightly improved version of the original Odyssey (the ball would now bounce back if it hit the top or bottom of the screen) with no overlays or game cards to change the behavior of the ball and paddles - pretty much all Odyssey owners just played the table tennis "Pong" game and ignored all the other games that involved overlays and shit, so they could massively reduce cost by just leaving all that crap out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622512
Yeah, the original Odyssey was less "video game" and more like a box of board games with the Odyssey itself as the central component they were all designed around. It was after that they were able to zero in on what was actually fun about the thing and start building on that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622572
It took a while, really. Here's the Odyssey 100 in action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZWPt8XHRUak

>still has the same general button setup as the Odyssey, with one dial for controlling vertical movement, one for controlling horizontal movement and one for controlling English per player, as well as one dial for controlling ball speed and one dial for controlling the position of the line
>the serve button has been removed, instead the player whose turn it is can serve the ball by touching the line (which actually gives it a gameplay function in the table tennis game instead of just being a visual indicator for where the rules said you "were allowed" to go, like on the original Odyssey. It still serves as such an indicator here though, the paddles can still go wherever they want on the screen and players need to police each other to follow the rules)
>the game still does not keep score, but now it has plastic sliders on the console to make it easier to keep count
>as mentioned, hitting the top or bottom of the screen will now make the ball bounce off, which probably feels a bit weird with the entire English paddle thing that otherwise gives you complete control over where the ball goes
>there's also a second selectable game, hockey, where the line gets a hole in the middle and needs to be placed at the left side of the screen, while a second, similar line will appear on the right side. Hitting the ball with these will have the same effect as if that player's paddle had hit it

It all looks and feels very very awkward and clumsy, not to mention extremely primitive compared to Atari's Pong consoles that WERE out at the time. They hadn't quite yet zeroed in on exactly what made Pong a better game than Odyssey Table Tennis.

posts.com:
>>9622221
>S-Video didn't even exist until after the NES was already on the market. A 1990 TV with S-Video would have possibly been even more than $500. It would be the top of the line.

The Super Nintendo has an official S-Video cable. When S-Video first rolled out for TV sets, they were pretty limited to TV's that were 27inch or bigger. 25inch TV's and smaller would not have S-video output back in 1991. Though in the later half of the 90's, there were smaller sets with S-video. Component wasn't even a thing until 1998 or 1999. The GameCube, PS2 and OG Xbox all had component connectors. The Dreamcast was a bit early for component, but has VGA and Svideo. Sadly the genesis did not have any s-video options, and on't RF or composite RCA connectors. The Saturn was the first Sega console with Svideo.

>THPS4 is the best one
THPS4 fails as a Tony Hawk game by not being fun to play a second time. You can't execute challenges on demand; you have to first talk to the person. Not only does this mean you can't to other challenges simultaneously, it gets even worse because of the time sinks in its own right like finding the person and then waiting for their congratulations to end. None of the challenges are particularly interesting on their own, the whole game plays like the slog final run you gave a level in previous games when you only had one challenge left to clear. The result is a very slowly paced game. Every criticism I've made of THPS4 here is a non-issue in THUG2, not even counting the excellent classic mode.

>>9618943

RT5X with CRT effect at 8:7 on a modest-but-not-large monitor with a little smudging to soften it slightly. it's not authentic with how it does the masks, but it's idealized for something that targets 1080p. the RT4K will do individual phosphor emulation.

alternatively, having a CRT of any kind that doesn't have fucked (mostly just asymmetry) geometry works. CRT shaders that emulate distortion often go way too far and exaggerate what would be minimized by calibration in the first place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I remember tearing apart my xbox 360 and cleaning out shitloads of cat hair and fixing the RROD. Even the radioshack employee who sold the thermal paste smugly asked me if I was doing that. It worked for a few more years until the video card melted.
Modding the original xbox is a great experience, if only for putting a huge hard drive on it and custom firmware. That thing is a monument to modern media players.
The PS2 has physical locks that you can bypass. The PSP with pandora batteries as well. The whole modchipping scene is now popular with Switch consoles. Now a freemcboot card can be bought easily and do everything you want.
I’ve heard of DJs modding game boy colors to output MIDI and using them as chiptune effects. It’s a very niche genre but I think people here can at least appreciate sounds from original hardware.
The PortableWii scene is interesting. Very interesting. There’s a whole world here to explore.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've done a bunch of mods. Here's a brief list:
Famicom composite (worthless*)
Mega drive 60Hz (worthless*)
Gameboy backlight/bivert (mediocre, lots of ghosting, angles are fucky)
GBA chink AGS-101 swap (great to look at, but holding a GBA isn't comfortable as an adult)
PS1 modchip (worthless*)
Dreamcast GD-emu, fan swap (great, although the fan swap needed some extra work)
N64 RGB mod (great)
Xbox 128mb swap (worthless, I wanted to play VC3 but there's no good way to get a lightgun working on it)
Switch joycon d-pad shell (inferior shiny plastic, but having a d-pad is too important. I use them in the grip anyway, so you barely notice it)

Softmods:
PS2 freeMCboot, HDD>SD adapter (great)
Xbox softmod (great)
Wii softmod (great)

All the worthless* are for mods that were superseded by MiSTer, at the time they were okay.

I'd recommend just grabbing some old electronic devices you don't care about anymore and going wild on these. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9615008
Buy a soldering iron (ideally one with temp control), buy one of those little copper wire cleaning balls, buy some solder. You're done, now go try and solder shit to and from random old crap you have lying around until you get the idea.

Soldering is easy as shit. Soldering neatly? That's a different story, but you can get away with fairly ugly joints no problem, just give them a bit of a tug to check.

>>9616652
Is there any chance that you're using a microSDHC card with an old microSD to SD adapter? I have quite a few of these around the house and some of them simply refuse to work with the faster/newer microSDHC cards. Worst case scenario, you could consider using a small form factor USB drive, like proper tiny one that won't stick out of the PS2 and booting games through OPL straght from that. Them tiny USB sticks come in really large sizes (capacity-wise I mean) nowadays, they cost next to nothing and you really don't have to worry about read and write speeds, because the PS2 won't get faster than 1mb/s, which is still faster than using discs.

I've modded and repaired a ton of systems and games that were on their last legs. I do it to try to keep as much vidya from going into the trash bin.
I still feel really bad about mods that irreversibly change the OG hardware tho.
For example I found a Atari 2600 6 switcher and have been cleaning it this week. I now got it running, but a composite mod would be nice and easy to do...
But I would just feel conflicted about it since there is only so many left in the world, history, etc.
At the end of the day it's your stuff, do what you want. Some mods are pretty cool... but have some class.
If its broke and you don't want it- give or sell it to someone who is capable of fixing it.
Don't be the person that spray paints consoles gold and slaps leds on them, or guts a nes and puts a raspberry pi in it to show "how much of a quirky geek you are!" or the fuck ever.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Rocky and Bullwinkle on NES is a fuckin' joke. The graphics are absolute shit. The sprites look like they were drawn by a three-year-old, and the animation is so choppy it makes me wanna puke. The audio is worse. The music is so repetitive and annoying, it's like someone just mashed a bunch of random notes together and called it a day. I'm sure the developers thought it was 'cute' or 'clever', but it's just fuckin' terrible.

The gameplay is just as bad. The controls are sluggish and unresponsive, like trying to drive a car with a broken transmission. The hit detection is a disaster, too. You'll jump into enemies and take damage for no fuckin' reason at all. And the levels? Don't even get me started. They're filled with cheap traps and enemies that are placed just out of reach, forcing you to take damage or miss a jump.

All in all, Rocky and Bullwinkle on NES is one of the worst games ever made. The graphics, audio, and gameplay are all so abysmal, it's a fuckin' insult to the gaming industry. If you want a good old-school game, look elsewhere.

ST was generally weaker than Amiga (except for raw CPU speed which was important mostly for 3D games), so many studios were using ST as a baseline system and developing ports to more powerful system later. The same reason why people kept releasing OCS-compatible Amiga games in the 90s instead of taking advantage of AGA specs.

Seems like the discussion is converging on a dungeon crawler. Out of all the suggestions I find doing it for the C64 to be the most convenient since there's an llvm backend, thus it could be written in a high level language and should allow simple ports to other 6502 platforms. I think it's more interesting to do a different platform each Zniggy release for comparison's sake, anyways.
I'll implement whatever designs you guys come up with as long as it's possible to do so.

well, it's something...
but the tooling for maps and tilesets are all over the place.
half the shit just doesn't work or works rather poorly, so it's a major pain in the ass to convert images to tilesets, and save tilemaps

1. import plain png as tilesets using only 4 colors

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616723
>it improves upon the original in every meaningful way
You are now forced to obtain the sword key as Jill, reducing exploration options.
The keys are now obtained in a set order, meaning that sequence breaking and seeing unique scenes is no longer possible.
Rebecca only appears with Richard, which was a hidden event in the original game.
When fighting against Yawn, in the original 3 events could occur dependent on the choices the player made throughout the game. You either have to get the antidote yourself, play a sequence as the partner character, or are carried by the partner character. Only the first event occurs in the remake due to the complete removal of all choices.
The true opening of the game is changed and made nonsensical. In the original, the player would be left in the main hall after the first encounter with any door to choose from. In the remake, all of the paths are locked or are immediate dead ends, with the only actual path being a linear straight line to get a crossbow, filled with constant tutorializing the original never had (in addition to the remake still having Barry say he'd be searching over there, which he isn't).
All optional rooms from the original are made mandatory with the exception of the aquarium office, but that contains the crest that unlocks the magnum so it is basically not optional.
Getting the crank is turned from a couple seconds of stair pushing to a walk down a straight forest path (which makes no sense as the reason they don't leave the mansion is because of the dogs, and dogs never spawn here). You go through two "puzzles" that essentially solve themselves with how braindead they are, and it concludes with the laughable first Lisa encounter, where she knocks you out and then does... nothing before fighting you when you wake up.
The Guardhouse is turned into a straight line with zero exploration despite that area being the most open to expansions given its size in the original concepts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616780
>walk down a straight forest path
This part always baffled me too. That was a prime opportunity to add some neat stuff but it's just a long, boring empty path. There's 1 zombie on the first trip and a couple more when you have to backtrack all the way from the cabin to the main hall, which was another retarded decision but that's a different topic, but none of them are even placed so they can really obstruct you. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616723
>>9616780
The process of getting anything done in Neptune's room is extended to the point of annoyance, turning a relatively short sequence into a several minutes long one of running around in a very dull and very empty environment, complete with a return trip if you want to use the V-Jolt. You also lose the box pushing path for seemingly no reason other than to force the player to use the other door for equally little reason.
The library in the mansion is reduced from 3 rooms, one hidden and one hosting a puzzle, complete with their own files and unique environments, into a more generic library to be a boss arena for a far easier Yawn boss fight. None of the elements of the original library are replicated.
The Yawn boss room is turned into an incredibly simple pushing puzzle where going through the grave is now mandatory, instead of being optional.
The hunters are less of a threat since the game adds shortcuts that reduces their presence in route planning immeasurably.
The caves are expanded but nothing interesting is added, just another box pushing puzzle.
The "lore" surrounding Lisa is the BOW equivalent of a Mary Sue, where she's incredibly special and important to every advancement Birkin made and is also partly immortal.
The caves not leading right into the lab results in several minutes of time wasting where the player runs through pretty much entirely empty hallways in a straight line back to the main hall.
The MO Disk Hunt only starting in the lab reduces any interesting exploration for the player, effectively making them not think about the future by removing any items that will be used in the future.
The lab puzzles are pretty much the same, just with extra steps, while the lab itself has zero expansions whatsoever beyond literal walking towards the end.
The game removes all past unlockables from RE1 and replaces them, meaning no original costumes, weapons, or modes. This means no Battle Game or Advanced Mode.
It sucks.
